entry.title: Bonnie J. Dunbar (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that NASA astronaut Bonnie J. Dunbar (pictured) flew on five space missions and has spent more than 50 days in space?

entry.title: The Scout Mindset (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that The Scout Mindset, a book about being able to change one's mind, took five years to be published partly because author Julia Galef changed her mind about what to write?

entry.title: J. Nash McCrea (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that 17-year-old cyclist J. Nash McCrea, nicknamed "Crash", caused a major crash at the 1904 Olympics?

entry.title: Woking (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that H. G. Wells wrote the majority of The War of the Worlds while living in Woking, and much of the novel is set in the local area?

entry.title: Liberian National Transitional Government (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that through their participation in the Liberian National Transitional Government, warlords could gain access to state resources whilst continuing hostilities between each other?

entry.title: Existential Physics (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that physicist Sabine Hossenfelder's book Existential Physics discusses whether free will, the multiverse, the existence of God, and the meaning of life are topics that science can answer?

entry.title: Dylan Schmidt (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that trampolinist Dylan Schmidt is New Zealand's first Olympic medallist in any gymnastics discipline?

entry.title: Private Peaceful (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the name of the book Private Peaceful came from a misspelled gravestone?
